# Task

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example



# Data

wrap_string("This function will wrap words into lines")

```julia
function wrap_string(text, text_width=10)
    wrapped_text = ""
    for word in split(text, " ")
        # Check if the current line would exceed the width
        if length(wrapped_text) * text_width + length(word) > text_width
            # Add a new line and start a new one with the current word
            wrapped_text *= "\n"
            wrapped_text += word
        else
            # If not, just add the word to the current line
            wrapped_text *= " "
            wrapped_text += word
        end
    end
    return wrapped_text
end

# Example
wrapped_string = wrap_string("This function will wrap words into lines", 12)
println(wrapped_string)
```

In this example, I've defined a `wrap_string` function that takes a text and a maximum text width as input. The function iterates over the words in the text and wraps them onto new lines when the line would exceed the given width. The final wrapped string is returned by the function.

The example demonstrates how to use the `wrap_string` function with a specific width (12 characters in this case).
